doc.field: Euro-dollar to be delayed one year?

The federal government is apparently considering delaying the introduction of the unified European currency, the euro, by one year. According to a news report, the green light for monetary union is only supposed to come in the year 2000. Nevertheless, the changeover to the new currency is still supposed to be completed by 2002. Hence, the schedule would be shortened from 3 years to 2. Within Germany's governing coalition, it is being said that it would be better to stop the countdown for a year than to start with a weak currency. The suggestion must not be made by Germany, some say, however, but rather by another European partner, such as France.
Still no breakthrough in budget stand-off

The coalition continues to grapple for a way out of the current budget crisis today. The problem is how to fill a gap in the tens of billions of Marks over this year and next. A round of talks between leading member of the CDU/CSU and the FDP this morning ended without tangible results. The two parties still disagree on what course to follow; as they diplomatically put it following today's discussion, they are still in the middle of negotiations. Even though today's talk, at least the third episode of tax-related rancour within the coalition, failed to achieve a settlement, the representatives of both sides in the Bundestag are going to debate tax reforms in a special sitting, even though, officially at least, no concrete suggestion is on the table yet. The SPD called on the government to be honest on the subject of lowering the Solidarity Supplement, as the promised reduction amounted to DM 7.5 billion, which the country could not afford just now. However, the FDP rejects any delaying of the reduction.
Government against EU employment programme

The Opposition has accused the Government of failure in the fight against unemployment during a Bundestag debate on European policies. SPD representative Wieczorek-Zeul said her party would not vote in favour of the new EU treaty without a set of common European employment policies. Foreign Minister Kinkel had earlier, in an official government statement, rejected delaying the introduction of the euro. He also placed conditions on the Government's approval of a European employment programme. Kinkel said that EU-wide employment programmes must not come to be; Germany's government does not want any work programmes which are far removed from its citizens, and also cannot be financed. Instead, Kinkel wants individual national programmes to be better coordinated than heretofore; if that were to be the case, his government could approve a chapter on employment in the EU treaty. In his speech, Kinkel said that Germany and France were rowing in the same direction as far as Europe was concerned, the new French government was staying the course, and the success of the EU summit depended, as so often, on Germany and France not breaking ranks. He added that if any problems did arise at the summit, the federal government would clear them up at the future German-French summit in Poitier. Speaking in the direction of the SPD, Kinkel warned against criticizing monetary union, saying that whoever came out in favour of delaying it was hurting Germany.
CDU economic committee demands savings

The economic committee of the CDU has demanded that less money be spent on the unemployed, pensioners, and public employees. The chairman of the organization, Muhrmann (sp?), said that the goal of lowering the state's financial activity to 46 percent of GDP by the year 2000 must be adhered to despite lower-than-expected tax revenues. He rejected the idea of tax hikes, saying it was unacceptable to advance only the 'taking' provisions of the planned tax reform to 1998. Meanwhile, tax reform talks within the governing coalition have ended without agreement.
Herzog criticizes too-high tax burden

Federal President Herzog has criticized federal, state, and local levels of government for taking a much too large share of Germans' earnings. He told the Ludwig Erhardt Foundation that when the government takes more than half of the country's GDP, it has clearly gone beyond bearable levels. The president called for companies to be given more freedom so that they could innovate.
Employment offices begins apprenticeship drive

The employment offices, faced with a serious shortage of training positions for young people, are beginning an aggressive campaign to secure more. The Federal Labour Office has declared June 18 to be Apprenticeship Day. Workers in the employment offices will be going into businesses today to make the pitch for more training positions. Three months before the start of the new training year, authorities say there are still almost 23,000 young people across the country looking for a position.
Trades, and economic committee reject tax increases

The central association of German trades, as well as the CDU's own economic committee flatly reject tax increases as a means of filling budgetary gaps, supporting the position of the FDP, and rejecting suggestions from the CDU/CSU that the 'burdensome' provisions of the great tax reform be implemented ahead of schedule, next year. The opponents of that suggestion say that if the tax increases are implemented early, then the tax breaks must be as well. They are also calling for continued savings measures, especially in the area of social services. The trades association supports the early sale of federal Telekom shares. It is calling on the SPD not to block the estimated DM 12 billion in savings any longer in the Bundesrat. The trades are also distancing themselves from the lowering of secondary wage costs through an eco-tax, as the SPD is demanding. As to the euro, they have adopted the chancellor's position: it must come on schedule, or it will never come.
Police and fire departments demonstrate in Bonn

More than 10,000 policemen, firemen, and prison guards again protested against planned cuts to their pensions and supplements. Participants in the demonstration came from all parts of Germany. As early as yesterday several thousand of the public employees followed the union's call to protest.
Cellular phones and laptop computers to be banned on planes

The use of cellular phones and laptop computers in airplanes is to be legally banned. The federal cabinet approved a bill which would punish offences with up to 2 years' imprisonment. The use of the devices is already banned, as they can interfere with the on-board electronics of aircraft; however, there has been no threat of legal consequences until now.
Judgement in Lucona trial

Businessman Hans-Peter Daimler has been sentenced to 14 years' imprisonment in the Lucona trial, following almost 5 years of hearing evidence. The judgement from the Regional Court in Kiel reads that the 62-year-old is guilty of six counts of being an accessory to murder and of attempted murder; Daimler and his Viennese friend Udo Proksch are responsible for the sinking of the Dutch freighter Lucona 20 years ago. In that sinking, 6 of the 12-member crew died. The court also found Daimler guilty of attempted insurance fraud; he and Proksch had falsely declared the cargo to be uranium, and had insured it for about DM 33 million.
Agreement in wage negotiations in wholesale and export branch

Union and management have agreed to 100 percent sick pay until the year 2000, in the wage dispute in Baden-Wuerttemberg's wholesale and export branch. As well, the 100,000 employees in the branch will receive pay increases of 1.5 percent, retroactive to last April. In return, the National Union of Employees agreed to more flexible work hours. Sick pay is also one of the major topics of discussion at the contract talks for the insurance industry, being held in Duesseldorf today.
No immediate cuts in local passenger service at the railway

Germany will help expand local passenger service on the rails with over DM 22 billion between 1998 and 2003. Federal and state transportation ministers came to this agreement at a conference in Munich. With the agreement, talk of the German Railway abandoning large numbers of uneconomical lines has been ended. Plans to that effect had come to light in recent weeks. The transportation ministers wanted to have all the facts, and had asked departing railway boss, Hans Duerr, and his July 1 replacement, Johannes Ludewig, to meet with them. Following the meetings, the chairman of the transportation ministers' conference, Peter Fischer of Lower Saxony, said that the ministers had been happy to hear from the executive chairman of the German Railway Co. that no mass programme to eliminate lines was intended. Rather, the railway would continue to shut down only a few lines on which fewer than 10 trains a day ran and for which the usual assessment procedure included at look at economicalness.
Fewer and fewer people using buses and trains

Fewer people than ever are using the bus or the train for travelling. According to a report from the BAT Leisure Research Institute in Hamburg, only 1 person in 20 uses public transportation for day-trips or short holidays. Most of the respondents to the survey use their cars for such trips.
Bank secrecy can be limited

The Federal Fiscal Court has ruled that bank secrecy can be limited. The Revenue Office is within its rights to examine bank accounts when it has good reason to believe that someone has not declared all of their accrued interest for tax purposes. The so-called Interest Deduction Law has been in effect since the end of 1992.
New Rhine bridge to be built

The federal cabinet this morning approved the construction of a new bridge across the Rhine, near Offenburg. The traffic bridge is to be built between Altenheim and Eschau, and will connect Germany and France. Construction is set to begin before the year 2000. The costs of approximately DM 55 million will be shared between Baden-Wuerttemberg and France.
More listeners for ARD broadcasters

Radio stations belonging to the ARD increased their listenership by just over 600,000 people last year, according to the 1996 media analysis, published today. Figures indicate that on an average workday, about 35.3 million Germans tune in to at least one ARD station.
Births up

The number of births in Germany went up last year for the first time since 1990. According to the Federal Statistics Office, almost 800,000 babies were born in Germany in 1996. That is up 4 percent over the previous year; the increase was especially large in eastern Germany, where it was up 11 percent. Even with this increase, the birthrate still falls short of replacement numbers: 87,000 people more died than were born last year.
Drastic jump in number of people on social assistance

There were many more people receiving social assistance last year than previously. The Federal Statistics Office is reporting that at the end of 1995, just over 1.3 million households were receiving social aid. That is 11 percent more than in 1994. On average, each household received DM 803 a month in 1995. The average time spent on social assistance was 27 months. Single women depended on social assistance or the longest periods - 3.5 years, on average.
Daimler subsidiary can take over Ford's heavy transport business in USA

Authorities in Canada and the U.S. have approved a take-over of Ford's heavy transport business by a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz. Thus, Daimler-Benz can achieve approximately a 40 percent market share of the North American heavy truck market. The company expects an increase in revenues of over $1 billion (US) from the take-over.
Tennis: Becker advances

Boris Becker has reached the quarter finals in the Halle international tennis tournament. He won today with 6:3 and 6:4 against the hometown hero Henrik Dreekmann. Becker faces American Jeff Tarango in the next round.
